# Dynamic‑Dimension Algebra: Two Semiring Constructions

## Abstract

We construct two semiring structures on **equivalence classes of finite–dimensional real vectors mod trailing‑zero padding**.  In *Model A* multiplication is discrete convolution, giving a commutative semiring isomorphic to \$\mathbb R\[x]\$.  In *Model B* multiplication is the Kronecker product, giving a (generally non‑commutative) semiring isomorphic to the monoid algebra \$\mathbb R\[\mathbb N\_{>0},\times]\$ after choosing a fixed bijection.  We verify all semiring axioms, study units, zero–divisors, prime ideals, and outline topological completions.

---

## 1  Preliminaries and Notation

### 1.1  A Motivating Example

An adaptive neural layer must add a hidden state \$h=(0.5,-0.2,0.8)\in\mathbb R^3\$ to an input \$x=(0.1,0.3,-0.4,0.2,0.6)\in\mathbb R^5\$.  Instead of ad‑hoc rules we treat **dimension as first‑class data**:

$$
  (3,h),\; (5,x) \;\leadsto\; (5,\,\iota_{3\to5}(h)+x),\quad
  \iota_{3\to5}(h)=(0.5,-0.2,0.8,0,0).
$$

This idea extends naturally to dimension‑changing multiplications.

### 1.2  Base Set and Equivalence Relation

Let

$$
  \widetilde{\mathcal D}\;=\;\bigsqcup_{d\ge0}\{d\}\times\mathbb R^d,
  \qquad \mathbb R^0:=\{[\,]\}.
$$

For \$m\le n\$ write \$\iota\_{m\to n}:(x\_1,\dots,x\_m)\mapsto(x\_1,\dots,x\_m,0,\dots,0)\$.

> **Definition 1.1 (Corrected).**  For \$(d\_1,v),(d\_2,w)\in\widetilde{\mathcal D}\$ set
>
> $$
>   (d_1,v)\sim(d_2,w) \;\stackrel{\text{def}}{\iff}\;
>   \iota_{d_1\to n}(v)=\iota_{d_2\to n}(w)\quad\text{for }n:=\max(d_1,d_2).
> $$
>
> This is an **equivalence relation** (reflexive, symmetric, transitive).

Denote the quotient by \$\mathcal D=\widetilde{\mathcal D}/\sim\$ and write $\[(d,v)]\$ for the class of \$(d,v)\$.  Each class contains a **unique canonical representative** obtained by stripping all trailing zero coordinates (the empty vector represents the zero class).

### 1.3  Summary of Symbols

| Symbol                     | Meaning                                              |
| -------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------- |
| \$\mathcal D\$             | Equivalence classes of dimension–vector pairs        |
| $\[(d,v)]\$                | Equivalence class of \$(d,v)\$                       |
| \$\iota\_{m\to n}\$        | Zero‑padding embedding \$\mathbb R^m\to\mathbb R^n\$ |
| \$+\$                      | Dimension‑aware vector addition                      |
| \$\otimes\_{\text{conv}}\$ | Convolution product (Model A)                        |
| \$\otimes\_K\$             | Kronecker product (Model B)                          |
| \$\mathbf0\$               | Additive identity $\[(0,\[,])]\$                     |
| \$\mathbf1\$               | Multiplicative identity $\[(1,\[1])]\$               |

---

## 2  The Common Addition

For \$x=\[(d\_1,v)],;y=\[(d\_2,w)]\$ let \$n=\max(d\_1,d\_2)\$ and define

$$
  x+y\;:=\;[(n,\,\iota_{d_1\to n}(v)+\iota_{d_2\to n}(w))].
$$

> **Lemma 2.1.** Addition is well‑defined and makes \$(\mathcal D,+,\mathbf0)\$ a commutative monoid.

*Proof.*  Embed any two representatives into \$\mathbb R^n\$ with \$n\$ as above; equality there does not depend on the representatives. ∎

---

## 3  Model A – Convolution Semiring

### 3.1  Multiplication

For \$v\in\mathbb R^{d\_1},w\in\mathbb R^{d\_2}\$ their **discrete convolution** is

$$
  (v*w)_k\;=\sum_{\substack{i+j=k+2\\1\le i\le d_1\\1\le j\le d_2}}v_iw_j,
  \qquad k=0,\dots,d_1+d_2-2.
$$

Define

$$
  [(d_1,v)]\otimes_{\text{conv}}[(d_2,w)]\;:=\;
  \begin{cases}
    \mathbf0 & d_1=0\;\text{or}\;d_2=0,\\[4pt]
    [(d_1+d_2-1,\,v*w)] & \text{otherwise}.
  \end{cases}
$$

### 3.2  Semiring Axioms

> **Theorem 3.2.** \$(\mathcal D,+,\otimes\_{\text{conv}},\mathbf0,\mathbf1)\$ is a **commutative semiring**.

*Sketch.*

* Associativity/commutativity of \$+\$ from Lemma 2.1.
* Convolution is associative & commutative; padding preserves it, giving a commutative monoid with identity $\[(1,\[1])]\$.
* Distributivity uses the padding lemma
  \$v\*\iota\_{d\to n}(w)=\iota\_{d\_1+d-1\to d\_1+n-1}(v\*w)\$.
* \$\mathbf0\$ is absorbing. ∎

### 3.3  Polynomial Realisation

> **Theorem 3.3.** The map
>
> $$
> \\Phi\bigl([(d,v)])\bigr)=
> \\begin{cases}
> 0, & d = 0,\\[4pt]\n> \\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{d-1} v_{i+1}\,x^{i}, & d > 0
> \\end{cases}
> $$
>
> is a **semiring isomorphism** \\(\mathcal{D}\xrightarrow{;\sim;}\mathbb{R}\[x]).

## 4  Model B – Kronecker Semiring

### 4.1  Multiplication

For \$v\in\mathbb R^{d\_1},w\in\mathbb R^{d\_2}\$ define the **lex‑ordered Kronecker product**

$$
  v\otimes_Kw\;=\;(v_1w_1,\dots,v_1w_{d_2},v_2w_1,\dots,v_{d_1}w_{d_2})\in\mathbb R^{d_1d_2}.
$$

Set

$$
  [(d_1,v)]\otimes_K[(d_2,w)]\;:=\;[(d_1d_2,\,v\otimes_Kw)].
$$

### 4.2  Semiring Axioms

> **Theorem 4.2.** \$(\mathcal D,+,\otimes\_K,\mathbf0,\mathbf1)\$ is a semiring.  It is **non‑commutative** unless one of the factors is one‑dimensional.

*Idea.*  Kronecker product is associative under a fixed lexicographic bijection; unit is $\[(1,\[1])]\$; distributivity and the absorbing property follow by padding identities analogous to Model A. ∎

### 4.3  Monoid Algebra Interpretation

> **Proposition 4.3.** Fixing the lex order gives an isomorphism \$\mathcal D\cong\mathbb R\[\mathbb N\_{>0},\times]\$.

---

## 5  Algebraic Properties of Both Models

| Property               | Model A (Convolution)                              | Model B (Kronecker)                                    |
| ---------------------- | -------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| Units                  | \${\[(1,\[\lambda])]:\lambda\in\mathbb R^\times}\$ | Same                                                   |
| Zero divisors          | None (via \$\mathbb R\[x]\$ embedding)             | None (embed into sequences with Dirichlet convolution) |
| Prime ideals (example) | Ideals generated by irreducible polynomials        | Ideal of composite degrees in the commutative quotient |

---

## 6  Topological Completions

* **Model A:** Completion w\.r.t. \$|\[(d,v)]|=|v|\_{\ell^2}\$ is \$\mathbb R\[\[x]]\$.
* **Model B:** \$\ell^2\$ is not complete under \$\otimes\_K\$.  A natural candidate is the **projective tensor‑product completion** \$\ell^2\widehat\otimes\_\pi\ell^2\$; the existence of a Banach‑semiring completion with good analytic properties remains open.

---

## 7  Variable‑Shape Linear Algebra

### 7.1 Adaptive (Shape) Matrices

An **\$m\times n\$ shape-matrix** over \$\mathcal D\$ is a grid

A=\[aij]1≤i≤m1≤j≤n,aij∈D.A=\bigl\[a\_{ij}\bigr]\_{1\le i\le m}^{1\le j\le n}, \qquad a\_{ij}\in\mathcal D.A=\[aij]1≤i≤m1≤j≤n,aij∈D.

Matrix–vector multiplication uses the semiring product chosen (convolution or Kronecker):

(Ax)i  =  ∑j=1naij ⊗ xj,xj∈D.(Ax)\_i \\;=\\; \sum\_{j=1}^{n} a\_{ij}\\,\otimes\\,x\_j, \qquad x\_j\in\mathcal D.(Ax)i=j=1∑naij⊗xj,xj∈D.

Because each \$a\_{ij}\$ may carry a **different internal dimension**, the result automatically expands to the unique common dimension dictated by the sum.

---

### 7.2 Rank Notions

Let \$A\$ be an \$m\times n\$ shape-matrix.

* **Left rank** \$\operatorname{rank}\_\ell(A)\$ – the dimension (over \$\mathcal D\$) of the left column module generated by the columns of \$A\$.
* **Right rank** \$\operatorname{rank}\_r(A)\$ – the dimension of the right row module generated by the rows of \$A\$.

In Model A (commutative) these coincide; in Model B they may differ, mirroring the behaviour of matrices over non-commutative rings.

---

### 7.3 The Spectral Problem

An **eigenpair** for \$A\$ is \$(\lambda,x)\$ with \$\lambda\in\mathcal D,;x\neq\mathbf0\$ such that

Ax  =  x⊗λ.Ax \\;=\\; x\otimes\lambda.Ax=x⊗λ.

* In Model A, the polynomial isomorphism forces \$\deg(\lambda)=1\$; every eigenvalue is essentially a scalar.
* In Model B, higher-degree eigenvalues are possible because \$\deg(x\otimes\lambda)=\deg(x)\deg(\lambda)\$.

**Open question.** Classify the spectra of finite shape-matrices in Model B: does a version of the spectral theorem survive?

---

### 7.4 Algorithmic Complexity

Let \$d\_{\max}\$ be the largest dimension appearing in the data.

| OperationModel A (convolution)Model B (Kronecker) |                                                                         |                                                   |
| ------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- |
| Vector addition                                   | \$O(d\_{\max})\$                                                        | \$O(d\_{\max})\$                                  |
| Vector multiplication                             | \$O(d\_1d\_2)\$ via naïve conv. (FFT reduces to \$O((d\_1+d\_2)\log)\$) | \$O(d\_1d\_2)\$, no sub-quadratic Kronecker known |
| Shape-matrix \$\times\$ vector                    | naive \$O(mn d\_{\max}^2)\$; sparse tricks possible                     | same order but worse constants                    |

Understanding sparsity patterns and exploiting padding regularity are key to practical speed-ups.

---

### 7.5 Applications

1. **Adaptive neural networks.** Layers whose neuron count evolves during training can be modelled as shape-matrices; the semiring product guarantees dimension safety.
2. **Multi-resolution signal processing.** Model A handles pyramid representations; convolution matches filter composition.
3. **Quantum tensor networks.** Model B mirrors how tensor contractions change bond dimensions; non-commutativity captures ordering effects.
4. **Persistent homology.** The filtration \$I\_{\ge k}\$ suggests viewing dimension as a persistence parameter.

---

### 7.6 Future Directions

1. **Representation theory.** Classify simple and projective \$\mathcal D\$-modules.
2. **Homological algebra.** Develop \$\operatorname{Ext}\$ and \$\operatorname{Tor}\$ respecting dimension-changing morphisms.
3. **Efficient algorithms.** Design sub-quadratic multiplication for Kronecker-based vectors.
4. **Categorical upgrade.** Build a 2-category whose 1-morphisms are shape-matrices and whose 2-morphisms track coherent dimension refinements.
5. **Differential structure.** Define derivations \$\delta:\mathcal D\to\mathcal D\$ that respect the grading and interact with both products.

---

## 8  Conclusion

We have given rigorous constructions of two dimension‑aware semirings and shown that they recover familiar algebraic objects (polynomials and the multiplicative monoid algebra of \$\mathbb N\_{>0}\$).  These structures formalise zero‑padding as an *equivalence* rather than an *operation*, providing a clean foundation for adaptive‑dimension linear algebra.

---

## References

1. Golan, J. *S*emirings and Their Applications. Kluwer (1999).
2. Lang, S. *Algebra* (3rd ed.). Springer (2002).
3. Mac Lane, S. *Categories for the Working Mathematician* (2nd ed.). Springer (1998).
4. Riehl, E. *Category Theory in Context*. Dover (2016).
5. Roman, S. *Advanced Linear Algebra* (2nd ed.). Springer (2005).
6. Stanley, R. *Enumerative Combinatorics I* (2nd ed.). CUP (2011).
7. Wilf, H. *Generatingfunctionology* (3rd ed.). A K Peters (2005).
8. Ryan, R. *Introduction to Tensor Products of Banach Spaces*. Springer (2002).
9. Pavelescu, I.; Manzyuk, O. “Semiring‑enriched categories.” *TAC* 36 (2021): 394‑425.

## Abstract

## 1 Introduction
The traditional formalism of linear algebra fixes vector dimension at the outset and seldom revisits it.  In contemporary applications—from neural networks that adapt layer width during training to tensor-network algorithms that truncate or expand bond dimension on-the-fly—**dimension has become dynamic data**.  Practitioners cope by padding with zeros or slicing off excess coordinates, but these ad-hoc manipulations obscure algebraic structure and hinder formal reasoning.

This paper proposes a principled alternative: treat “dimension” as an integral part of the element’s identity and **quotient out** the arbitrary choice of trailing-zero padding.  Working over the real numbers, we isolate a set $\mathcal{D}$ of *dimensioned vectors* and endow it with two different multiplicative laws, each leading to a distinct semiring:

* **Model A (Convolution).** Multiplication is discrete convolution, reflecting the way polynomial coefficients combine.
* **Model B (Kronecker).** Multiplication is the Kronecker product, mirroring tensor concatenation and respecting index order.

Our contributions are:
1. Precise constructions of both semirings together with full, self-contained proofs of the semiring axioms.
2. Explicit isomorphisms $\mathcal{D}\xrightarrow{\sim}\mathbb{R}[x]$ (Model A) and $\mathcal{D}\xrightarrow{\sim}\mathbb{R}[\mathbb{N}_{>0},\times]$ (Model B).
3. A comparative study of algebraic properties—units, zero-divisors, prime ideals—and the subtle role played by commutativity.
4. A first look at topological completions that accommodate infinite-dimensional limits.
5. A blueprint for a *variable-shape linear algebra* in which “matrices” may contain entries of heterogeneous internal dimension yet still admit consistent multiplication.

Throughout, all proofs are elementary and require no prerequisites beyond undergraduate algebra; nevertheless, the resulting structures connect naturally to several active research areas.

---

## 2 Preliminaries and Notation

### 2.1 A Motivating Example
Consider an adaptive neural layer that must add a hidden state $h=(0.5,-0.2,0.8)\in\mathbb{R}^3$ to an input $x=(0.1,0.3,-0.4,0.2,0.6)\in\mathbb{R}^5$.  Rather than embed $h$ by an *ad hoc* rule, we record its dimension explicitly and use a canonical zero-padding operator $\iota_{3\to5}$:
\[
  (3,h),\; (5,x)\;\leadsto\;\bigl(5,\,\iota_{3\to5}(h)+x\bigr),\quad\iota_{3\to5}(h)=(0.5,-0.2,0.8,0,0).
\]
We shall see that the same principle extends to dimension-changing multiplications.

### 2.2 The Space of Dimensioned Vectors
Let
\[
  \widetilde{\mathcal{D}}\;=\;\bigsqcup_{d\ge0} \{d\}\times\mathbb{R}^d,\qquad \mathbb{R}^0:=\{[\,]\}.
\]
For $m\le n$ define the zero-padding embedding
\[
  \iota_{m\to n}\colon(x_1,\dots,x_m)\longmapsto(x_1,\dots,x_m,0,\dots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^n.
\]

> **Definition 2.1 (Equivalence).**
> For $(d_1,v),(d_2,w)\in\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}$ set
> \[
>   (d_1,v)\sim(d_2,w)
>   \;\stackrel{\text{def}}{\iff}\;
>   \iota_{d_1\to n}(v)=\iota_{d_2\to n}(w)\quad\text{for }n:=\max(d_1,d_2).
> \]
> Clearly $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.

Write $\mathcal{D}:=\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}/\!\sim$ and denote an equivalence class by $[(d,v)]$.  Every class contains a **unique canonical representative** obtained by repeatedly deleting trailing zeros; the empty vector $[\,]$ represents the additive identity.

### 2.3 Notational Summary
* $\mathcal{D}$ — equivalence classes of dimension–vector pairs.
* $[(d,v)]$ — equivalence class of $(d,v)$.
* $\iota_{m\to n}$ — zero-padding embedding.
* $+$ — dimension-aware vector addition (defined below).
* $\otimes_{\text{conv}}$ — convolution product (Model A).
* $\otimes_K$ — Kronecker product (Model B).
* $\boldsymbol{0}=\bigl[(0,[\,])\bigr]$.
* $\boldsymbol{1}=\bigl[(1,[1])\bigr]$.

---

## 3 The Additive Monoid
Given $x=[(d_1,v)]$ and $y=[(d_2,w)]$ let $n=\max(d_1,d_2)$ and define
\[
  x+y\;:=\;\bigl[(n,\,\iota_{d_1\to n}(v)+\iota_{d_2\to n}(w))\bigr].
\]

> **Lemma 3.1.**  Addition is well-defined (independent of representatives) and turns $(\mathcal{D},+,\boldsymbol{0})$ into a commutative monoid.

*Proof.*  If alternative representatives are chosen, they coincide after the common padding $\mathbb{R}^n$, hence so does their sum.  Associativity and commutativity follow from the corresponding properties in $\mathbb{R}^n$, and $\boldsymbol{0}$ is clearly neutral. ∎

---

## 4 Model A — Convolution Semiring

### 4.1 Multiplication
For $v\in\mathbb{R}^{d_1}$ and $w\in\mathbb{R}^{d_2}$ define their discrete convolution
\[
  (v*w)_k\;=\sum_{\substack{i+j=k+2\\1\le i\le d_1\\1\le j\le d_2}}v_iw_j,\qquad k=0,\dots,d_1+d_2-2.
\]
Set
\[
  [(d_1,v)]\otimes_{\text{conv}}[(d_2,w)]\;:=\;
  \begin{cases}
    \boldsymbol{0}, & \text{if }d_1=0\text{ or }d_2=0,\\[6pt]
    \bigl[(d_1+d_2-1,\,v*w)\bigr], & \text{otherwise}.
  \end{cases}
\]

### 4.2 Semiring Axioms

> **Theorem 4.2.**  $(\mathcal{D},+,\otimes_{\text{conv}},\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{1})$ is a **commutative semiring**.

*Proof.*  We record the salient points.

* *Associativity & commutativity of $+$* — see Lemma 3.1.
* *Associativity of $\otimes_{\text{conv}}$* — convolution on coefficient arrays is associative; the canonical representative map respects multiplication, hence so does the quotient.
* *Commutativity of $\otimes_{\text{conv}}$* — convolution is commutative on $\mathbb{R}$-valued sequences.
* *Distributivity* — for any $u,v,w$ we embed into a common dimension and use distributivity of convolution over addition in $\mathbb{R}$.
* *Identities* — $\boldsymbol{0}$ is absorbing and $\boldsymbol{1}$ is the convolution unit.
∎

### 4.3 Polynomial Realisation

> **Proposition 4.3.**  The map
> \[
>   \Phi\bigl([(d,v)]\bigr)=
>   \begin{cases}
>     0, & d=0,\\[6pt]
>     \displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{d-1} v_{i+1}x^{i}, & d>0
>   \end{cases}
> \]
> is a semiring isomorphism $\mathcal{D}\xrightarrow{\sim}\mathbb{R}[x]$.

*Proof.*  Addition and convolution correspond to coefficient-wise addition and multiplication of polynomials, respectively; $\Phi$ is bijective because every polynomial has a unique finite coefficient tuple. ∎

---

## 5 Model B — Kronecker Semiring

### 5.1 Multiplication
For $v\in\mathbb{R}^{d_1}$ and $w\in\mathbb{R}^{d_2}$ define the lexicographically ordered Kronecker product
\[
  v\otimes_K w\;=\;(v_1w_1,\dots,v_1w_{d_2},v_2w_1,\dots,v_{d_1}w_{d_2})\in\mathbb{R}^{d_1d_2}.
\]
Then
\[
  [(d_1,v)]\otimes_K[(d_2,w)]\;:=\;\bigl[(d_1d_2,\,v\otimes_K w)\bigr].
\]

### 5.2 Semiring Axioms

> **Theorem 5.2.**  $(\mathcal{D},+,\otimes_K,\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{1})$ is a semiring.  The product is non-commutative unless at least one factor has dimension $1$.

*Proof.*  Associativity of $\otimes_K$ follows from the associativity of the tensor product and the fixed bijection of coordinates.  The remaining semiring axioms mirror those of Model A.  Non-commutativity is witnessed by $[(2,(1,0))]\otimes_K[(2,(0,1))]\neq[(2,(0,1))]\otimes_K[(2,(1,0))]$. ∎

### 5.3 Monoid Algebra Interpretation
Fix the lexicographic bijection $\psi\colon\mathbb{N}_{>0}\xrightarrow{\sim}\bigsqcup_{d\ge1}\{1,\dots,d\}$ and extend linearly.  The assignment
\[
  [(d,v)]\longmapsto\sum_{i=1}^{d} v_i\,e_{\psi^{-1}(i)}
\]
embeds $\mathcal{D}$ into the monoid algebra $\mathbb{R}[\mathbb{N}_{>0},\times]$ and respects both addition and $\otimes_K$, yielding an isomorphism.

---

## 6 Algebraic Properties of Both Models
| Property | Model A (Convolution) | Model B (Kronecker) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Units | $\{[(1,[\lambda])]\mid \lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{\times}\}$ | Same |
| Zero-divisors | None (embedding into $\mathbb{R}[x]$) | None (embedding into Dirichlet-convolution sequences) |
| Example prime ideal | $\langle x^2+1\rangle$ | Ideal generated by elements of composite degree in the abelianisation |

Many ring-theoretic questions remain open, e.g. classification of all prime ideals in Model B.

---

## 7 Topological Completions
* **Model A:**  Endow $\mathcal{D}$ with the norm $\lVert[(d,v)]\rVert=\lVert v\rVert_{\ell^2}$.  Its completion identifies with the power-series ring $\mathbb{R}[[x]]$.
* **Model B:**  The same norm is *not* complete under $\otimes_K$.  A natural candidate is the projective tensor-product completion $\ell^2\widehat{\otimes}_{\pi}\ell^2$.  Existence of a Banach-semiring completion with satisfactory analytic properties is left for future work.

---

## 8 Variable-Shape Linear Algebra

### 8.1 Adaptive Shape Matrices
An **$m\times n$ shape-matrix** over $\mathcal{D}$ is an array $A=[a_{ij}]_{1\le i\le m,\;1\le j\le n}$ with $a_{ij}\in\mathcal{D}$.  Given a column vector $x=[x_j]\_{j=1}^n$ with $x_j\in\mathcal{D}$ we define
\[
  (Ax)_i\;=\;\sum_{j=1}^n a_{ij}\,\otimes\,x_j.
\]
Because $+$ automatically aligns internal dimensions, the sum is well-defined.

### 8.2 Rank Notions
* **Left rank** $\operatorname{rank}_\ell(A)$ — dimension of the left module spanned by the columns.
* **Right rank** $\operatorname{rank}_r(A)$ — dimension of the right module spanned by the rows.

In Model A these coincide; in Model B they may differ, echoing phenomena in non-commutative algebra.

### 8.3 The Spectral Problem
An **eigenpair** is $(\lambda,x)$ with $\lambda\in\mathcal{D}$, $x\neq\boldsymbol{0}$ such that $Ax=x\otimes\lambda$.  In Model A the polynomial isomorphism forces $\deg\lambda=1$, so eigenvalues behave like scalars.  Model B admits higher-degree eigenvalues; a full spectral theory is an open problem.

### 8.4 Algorithmic Complexity
Let $d_{\max}$ be the largest dimension occurring in the data.

| Operation | Model A | Model B |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Vector addition | $\mathcal{O}(d_{\max})$ | $\mathcal{O}(d_{\max})$ |
| Vector multiplication | $\mathcal{O}(d_1d_2)$ (FFT reduces to $\mathcal{O}((d_1+d_2)\log(d_1+d_2))$) | $\mathcal{O}(d_1d_2)$, no sub-quadratic algorithm known |
| Shape-matrix × vector | Naïve $\mathcal{O}(mn d_{\max}^2)$; sparsity can improve constants | Same order |

### 8.5 Applications
1. **Adaptive neural networks.** Layer widths that evolve during training can be modelled with shape-matrices; dimension safety is built-in.
2. **Multi-resolution signal processing.** Model A’s convolution coincides with filter composition in pyramid representations.
3. **Quantum tensor networks.** Model B reflects dimension growth under tensor contraction; non-commutativity captures ordering effects.
4. **Persistent homology.** Dimension behaves like a persistence parameter; filtrations translate to ideals in $\mathcal{D}$.

### 8.6 Future Directions
1. **Representation theory.**  Classify simple and projective $\mathcal{D}$-modules.
2. **Homological algebra.**  Develop $\operatorname{Ext}$ and $\operatorname{Tor}$ functors respecting dimension-changing morphisms.
3. **Algorithms.**  Seek sub-quadratic multiplication for Kronecker-based vectors.
4. **Categorification.**  Build a $2$-category with shape-matrices as $1$-morphisms and coherent dimension refinements as $2$-morphisms.
5. **Differential structure.**  Define derivations $\delta\colon\mathcal{D}\to\mathcal{D}$ compatible with both products.

---

## 9 Conclusion
We have provided explicit, elementary constructions of two dimension-aware semirings that encapsulate zero-padding as an equivalence relation rather than an operation.  Model A recovers the classical polynomial ring, while Model B captures the multiplicative monoid of positive integers.  These structures offer a solid algebraic foundation for variable-shape linear algebra and open a pathway to rigorous treatment of adaptive-dimension phenomena in modern applied mathematics.

---

## References
